--- title: ST4SD Core --- import { CodeSyntax } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { NetworkServices } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { CarbonForIbmDotcom } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { Kubernetes } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { Build } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { Insights } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { Documentation } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { Reliability } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { CloudTutorials } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { Reset } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { Containers } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; import { Docker } from '@carbon/pictograms-react'; **ST4SD Core** is a python framework for automating computational science workflows. It enables researchers to create robust and reusable virtual experiments that can be deployed on HPC and cloud environments, or on their laptops. Any researcher comfortable with programming can start using ST4SD Core. ## Why ST4SD Core?
}> ST4SD Core provides features for writing virtual experiments that can run on your laptop, on HPC machines, or on cloud. }> Run expensive analytics in parallel with simulations, ensuring they complete shortly after simulations themselves. This also enables "on-the-fly" triggers based on the simulation behaviour, for example stopping criteria. }> We adopt a pattern of simple-specification, smart-runtime. Many execution details, for example data-transfer or restarting behaviour, are handled by ST4SD Core eliminating complexity and enabling researchers to focus on the computational process. }> Features including image checking, image pinning, unstable filesystem identification and enhanced exit-code handling, increase the chances that complex long-running workflow will complete successfully.
## Try it yourself Run a virtual experiment to calculate the geometric properties of a nanoporous material. `pip install "st4sd-runtime-core[develop]"`, which installs the command-line-tool `elaunch.py`, and execute:
python 3.7 to 3.10 tested
```bash : # Get the directory that provides input to the next command git clone https://github.com/st4sd/nanopore-geometry-experiment.git : # Run elaunch.py specifying certain files in the directory created above elaunch.py -l40 --nostamp --instanceName nanopore-geometry-experiment \ --manifest nanopore-geometry-experiment/manifest.yaml \ --input nanopore-geometry-experiment/docker-example/cif_files.dat \ --platform docker nanopore-geometry-experiment/conf/flowir_package.yaml ``` Note, this experiment requires that `docker` is installed on your laptop. The output of the `elaunch.py` command will be a directory called `nanopore-geometry-experiment.instance` in the same directory you ran `elaunch.py`. When the experiment is finished `cat nanopore-geometry-experiment.instance/output/properties.csv` for the measured properties of the material. To find out more about this experiment visit its [source repository](https://github.com/st4sd/nanopore-geometry-experiment.git). ## Learn more
}> Start with our [tutorial](/tutorial) to get an introduction to writing virtual experiments with ST4SD Core }> Learn about the repositories of [application images](/application-images/) maintained by ST4SD developers and community to quickly get started building experiments. } > Restarting long simulations due to hitting queue wall-times is very common in computational science. The [restart documentation](/restart) describes ST4SD Core features for handling this. } > We support running containerized applications using a native container runtime system but also on Kubernetes as Jobs. Check out our [documentation](/using-containers) for using containers in ST4SD.
## Accelerate your simulation research with ST4SD Check out these other ST4SD technologies. All are designed to work together to provide a powerful platform for simulation.
}> **ST4SD Cloud** creates and maintains secure, scalable and robust deployments of ST4SD on OpenShift clusters. [Get Started](/st4sd-cloud-getting-started) }> **ST4SD Registry** provides a UI for sharing and browsing virtual experiments. [Get Started](/st4sd-registry-getting-started) }> **ST4SD Services** allows scientists to run virtual experiments and query their data via Jupyter notebooks. It includes a high-performance metadata-store that enables memoization. [Get Started](/st4sd-services-getting-started)
